metadata.description: General HVAC knowledge - IMC code, safety, combustion air, fundamentals

questions.question: What does the International Mechanical Code (IMC) regulate?

choices.b: Design, installation, maintenance of mechanical systems including HVAC

explanation.short: The IMC covers design, installation, maintenance, alteration, and inspection of mechanical systems.
explanation.detailed: IMC scope includes: heating systems; cooling systems; ventilation; exhaust systems; duct systems; combustion air; chimneys and vents; hydronic piping; refrigeration. The code establishes minimum standards for safety and health. It's adopted by most US states with or without amendments. Used alongside IRC for residential and IBC for commercial construction.

questions.question: When is a mechanical permit typically required?

choices.b: For installation, alteration, or replacement of mechanical equipment

explanation.short: Permits are required for installing, altering, replacing, or repairing mechanical systems and equipment.
explanation.detailed: Permit requirements: new installations; equipment replacements (even like-for-like); alterations to existing systems; extensions of ductwork or piping. Exemptions may include: portable equipment; minor repairs; maintenance. Always verify local requirements - jurisdictions may have stricter rules. Working without required permits can result in fines and required removal of work.

questions.question: Why is adequate combustion air required for fuel-burning appliances?

choices.b: To provide oxygen for complete combustion and prevent CO production

explanation.short: Combustion air provides oxygen for complete fuel burning; insufficient air causes incomplete combustion and deadly CO.
explanation.detailed: Combustion air requirements: fuel needs oxygen to burn completely; insufficient oxygen = incomplete combustion; incomplete combustion produces carbon monoxide (CO); CO is colorless, odorless, and deadly. IMC Chapter 7 specifies: minimum air opening sizes; indoor vs outdoor air sources; calculation methods. Critical for: furnaces, boilers, water heaters, fireplaces. Tightly sealed homes require mechanical air supply.

questions.question: For indoor combustion air from adjacent spaces, what is the minimum free area required per 1,000 BTU/hr input?

choices.b: 2 sq in per 1,000 BTU/hr for each opening (two openings required)

explanation.short: Indoor combustion air requires two openings at 1 sq in per 1,000 BTU/hr each, totaling 2 sq in per 1,000 BTU/hr.
explanation.detailed: Indoor air method: requires TWO openings; one within 12 inches of ceiling, one within 12 inches of floor; each opening = 1 sq in per 1,000 BTU/hr; minimum 100 sq in each. Total room volume must also be adequate. Example: 100,000 BTU furnace needs 100 sq in upper and 100 sq in lower opening (minimum). Communicating spaces must have adequate volume.

questions.question: What is a direct-vent appliance?

choices.b: Sealed combustion - draws air from outside and vents to outside

explanation.short: Direct-vent appliances are sealed combustion units that draw combustion air from outdoors and vent exhaust outdoors.
explanation.detailed: Direct-vent (sealed combustion): combustion chamber isolated from indoor air; intake pipe brings outdoor air for combustion; exhaust pipe vents products outside; often concentric (pipe within pipe) or side-by-side. Benefits: doesn't deplete indoor oxygen; not affected by house pressure; higher efficiency; safer in tight homes. Required or preferred in many modern installations.

questions.question: What are symptoms of carbon monoxide exposure?

choices.b: Headache, dizziness, nausea, confusion (flu-like symptoms)

explanation.short: CO poisoning symptoms mimic the flu: headache, dizziness, weakness, nausea, confusion, and can progress to unconsciousness and death.
explanation.detailed: Carbon monoxide poisoning: CO binds to hemoglobin 200x stronger than oxygen; reduces blood's oxygen-carrying capacity; symptoms: headache, dizziness, weakness, nausea, vomiting, confusion, blurred vision; high levels cause unconsciousness and death. Often mistaken for flu. Multiple occupants with same symptoms = CO alert. CO detectors are critical. Technicians should carry personal CO monitors.

questions.question: What is the maximum acceptable CO level in flue gases for a properly operating gas furnace?

choices.b: Under 100 ppm air-free

explanation.short: Gas furnaces should produce under 400 ppm CO air-free in flue gases; levels above indicate combustion problems.
explanation.detailed: Flue gas CO levels (air-free measurement): Under 100 ppm = good combustion; 100-400 ppm = acceptable but monitor; Over 400 ppm = needs service/adjustment. Air-free measurement accounts for dilution air. Ambient CO in occupied space: OSHA limit 50 ppm (8-hr TWA); CO alarm typically triggers at 70 ppm. Causes of high CO: insufficient air, flame impingement, cracked heat exchanger, dirty burners.

questions.question: What is the danger of a cracked heat exchanger in a gas furnace?

choices.b: Combustion gases including CO can enter the supply air stream

explanation.short: A cracked heat exchanger allows combustion products including deadly CO to mix with heated air distributed to the home.
explanation.detailed: Cracked heat exchanger hazards: normally, combustion gases are isolated in heat exchanger; crack allows gases to enter supply airstream; CO distributed throughout building; potentially fatal. Detection: visual inspection (difficult); combustion analysis; elevated CO in supply air; flame disturbance when blower starts. If suspected: shut down furnace immediately; do not operate until repaired or replaced.

questions.question: How should natural gas leaks be detected?

choices.b: Electronic combustible gas detector or soap bubbles

explanation.short: Use electronic combustible gas detectors or soap bubble solution - NEVER use open flames to check for gas leaks.
explanation.detailed: Gas leak detection methods: electronic combustible gas detector (safest, most sensitive); soap bubble solution on joints/connections; gas company odorant (mercaptan) smell. NEVER use: open flame; matches; lighters. If major leak suspected: don't operate electrical switches; evacuate; call gas company from outside. Technicians should carry combustible gas detectors and use routinely.

questions.question: Where must a manual gas shutoff valve be located for HVAC equipment?

choices.b: Within 6 feet of the appliance and in the same room

explanation.short: A manual shutoff valve must be within 6 feet of the appliance and accessible in the same room.
explanation.detailed: Gas shutoff requirements: within 6 feet of appliance; same room or space as appliance; upstream of union or connector; accessible without tools; in addition to any appliance valve. Purpose: allows quick shutoff during emergency or service without going to meter. Sediment trap (drip leg) also required before appliance. These requirements are consistent across most codes.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a sediment trap (drip leg) on a gas line?

choices.b: To collect moisture and debris before it enters the appliance

explanation.short: Sediment traps collect moisture and debris from the gas supply to prevent blockage or damage to appliance controls.
explanation.detailed: Sediment trap (drip leg) purpose: gas lines can contain moisture, pipe scale, dirt; these contaminants can block orifices and damage valves; sediment trap collects debris by gravity; located at low point before appliance; typically 3-inch minimum length. Installation: tee fitting with capped nipple pointing down; installed after shutoff valve, before appliance connection. Required by code for most gas appliances.

questions.question: What determines the venting category of a gas appliance?

choices.b: Flue gas temperature and pressure (positive or negative)

explanation.short: Venting categories (I-IV) are based on flue gas temperature (above/below 140°F dew point) and pressure (positive/negative).
explanation.detailed: Venting categories: Category I - negative pressure, non-condensing (traditional); Category II - negative pressure, condensing (rare); Category III - positive pressure, non-condensing; Category IV - positive pressure, condensing (high-efficiency). Determines vent material requirements: Cat I can use B-vent; Cat IV needs plastic or stainless. High-efficiency condensing appliances (90%+) are typically Category IV.

questions.question: What vent material is typically required for Category IV appliances?

choices.b: B-vent
choices.c: PVC, CPVC, or stainless steel per manufacturer

explanation.short: Category IV appliances use PVC, CPVC, polypropylene, or stainless steel venting as specified by the manufacturer.
explanation.detailed: Category IV venting: produces acidic condensate; positive pressure pushes flue gases; requires: sealed joints, corrosion-resistant material. Common materials: PVC (up to 149°F), CPVC (up to 194°F), polypropylene, AL29-4C stainless steel. MUST follow manufacturer specifications - they've tested specific materials. Improper venting can cause: flue gas leakage, material degradation, CO poisoning. Slope to drain condensate.

questions.question: Where should condensate from high-efficiency furnaces be drained?

choices.b: To an approved drain, neutralizer may be required

explanation.short: Condensate must drain to an approved location; some jurisdictions require neutralization due to acidity.
explanation.detailed: Condensate disposal requirements: drain to floor drain, laundry sink, condensate pump, or approved point; condensate is acidic (pH 3-5) due to carbonic acid; some codes require neutralizer before drain; cannot discharge where it causes damage or hazard. Drain line: proper slope, trapped if required, sized adequately. Check local requirements - neutralization requirements vary by jurisdiction.

questions.question: What determines required clearances from combustible materials for HVAC equipment?

choices.b: Equipment listing, manufacturer instructions, and code minimums

explanation.short: Clearances are determined by equipment listing/labeling, manufacturer's instructions, and code minimum requirements.
explanation.detailed: Clearance determination hierarchy: manufacturer's listing takes precedence (they've tested the equipment); code provides minimums if not listed; never reduce below listed clearance without approved shield. Typical furnace clearances: 1 inch sides, 6 inches front for service. Vent clearances: B-vent = 1 inch; single-wall = 6 inches. Check equipment label and installation manual for specific requirements.

questions.question: What access is required for HVAC equipment per code?

choices.b: Sufficient access for inspection, service, repair, and replacement

explanation.short: Equipment must have clear access for inspection, servicing, repair, and replacement.
explanation.detailed: Access requirements: equipment cannot be installed where access is impaired; minimum clear working space required (varies by equipment); access opening to attic/crawlspace minimum 22x30 inches; passageway minimum 22 inches wide; light and receptacle at indoor equipment. Purpose: safety, maintenance, emergency service. Installing equipment without proper access is a code violation and makes service difficult/expensive.

questions.question: What additional requirements apply to equipment installed in attics?

choices.b: Access opening, passageway, lighting, service platform, and receptacle

explanation.short: Attic installations require adequate access opening, passageway, lighting, solid service platform, and electrical receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Attic installation requirements: access opening minimum 22x30 inches; passageway minimum 22 inches wide with solid flooring; light fixture with switch; electrical receptacle within 25 feet; level service platform at equipment (minimum 30x30 inches). If equipment in attic: drain pan with drain required for cooling equipment. These requirements ensure safe service access.

questions.question: When is an auxiliary drain pan required under cooling equipment?

choices.b: When equipment is installed where condensate overflow would cause damage

explanation.short: An auxiliary drain pan is required when equipment is above spaces where condensate overflow would cause property damage.
explanation.detailed: Auxiliary drain pan requirements: required in attics, over finished spaces, or where overflow causes damage; minimum 1.5 inches deep; extend 3 inches beyond equipment; drain to conspicuous location OR connect secondary drain with separate termination. Purpose: protect building from condensate overflow if primary drain clogs. Many systems also use float switches to shut down equipment if pan fills.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IMC auxiliary drain pan requirements

questions.question: What electrical disconnecting means is required for HVAC equipment?

choices.b: A disconnect within sight and readily accessible from equipment

explanation.short: A disconnecting means must be within sight and readily accessible from the equipment for safe service.
explanation.detailed: Electrical disconnect requirements: within sight of equipment (visible and within 50 feet); readily accessible (no tools needed); lockable in open position for service safety; typically a fused disconnect or non-fused switch. For indoor equipment, breaker may serve if within sight. Purpose: technician can verify power is off while at equipment. Never service energized equipment unless specifically required.

questions.question: What is a BTU (British Thermal Unit)?

choices.b: Amount of heat to raise 1 pound of water by 1°F

explanation.short: A BTU is the amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one pound of water by one degree Fahrenheit.
explanation.detailed: BTU (British Thermal Unit): standard unit of heat energy in US; 1 BTU = heat to raise 1 lb water 1°F; equipment rated in BTU/hr (input or output); 1 ton cooling = 12,000 BTU/hr; 1 therm natural gas = 100,000 BTU. Understanding BTUs essential for: load calculations, equipment sizing, efficiency calculations, fuel consumption estimates.

questions.question: How many BTU/hr equals one ton of refrigeration?

choices.b: 6,000 BTU/hr

explanation.short: One ton of refrigeration equals 12,000 BTU/hr of cooling capacity.
explanation.detailed: Ton of refrigeration: historically based on ice making - heat absorbed melting 1 ton of ice in 24 hours; 1 ton ice × 144 BTU/lb latent heat = 288,000 BTU/day; 288,000 ÷ 24 hours = 12,000 BTU/hr. Common AC sizes: 1.5 ton (18,000 BTU), 2 ton (24,000 BTU), 3 ton (36,000 BTU), 5 ton (60,000 BTU). Residential typically 1.5-5 tons; commercial can be much larger.

questions.question: What is sensible heat?

choices.b: Heat that changes temperature without phase change (can be 'sensed')

explanation.short: Sensible heat changes temperature without changing phase - it can be 'sensed' or measured with a thermometer.
explanation.detailed: Sensible heat: causes temperature change; can be measured (sensed) with thermometer; examples: heating air from 70°F to 90°F, heating water from 50°F to 100°F. Contrasts with latent heat (phase change at constant temperature). HVAC systems handle both: cooling removes sensible heat (lowers temperature) and latent heat (removes humidity). Sensible Heat Ratio (SHR) = sensible ÷ total heat.

questions.question: What is latent heat?

choices.b: Heat absorbed or released during phase change without temperature change

explanation.short: Latent heat is absorbed or released during phase change (solid↔liquid↔vapor) without changing temperature.
explanation.detailed: Latent heat: 'hidden' heat - doesn't change temperature; occurs during phase change; water: 144 BTU/lb to melt/freeze (fusion), 970 BTU/lb to vaporize/condense (vaporization). In HVAC: evaporator absorbs latent heat to evaporate refrigerant; condenser releases latent heat to condense refrigerant; dehumidification removes latent heat from air (condensing moisture).

questions.question: What is the specific heat of water?

choices.b: 1.0 BTU/lb·°F

explanation.short: Water has a specific heat of 1.0 BTU/lb·°F - the standard by which other materials are compared.
explanation.detailed: Specific heat: amount of heat to raise 1 lb of substance by 1°F. Water = 1.0 BTU/lb·°F (by definition of BTU). Air = 0.24 BTU/lb·°F (much easier to heat than water). Water's high specific heat makes it excellent for: hydronic heating, thermal storage, heat transfer. Used in calculations: Q = m × c × ΔT where c = specific heat.

questions.question: What does 50% relative humidity mean?

choices.b: Air holds half the water vapor it could hold at that temperature

explanation.short: 50% RH means air contains half the maximum water vapor it could hold at that temperature before condensation.
explanation.detailed: Relative humidity: ratio of actual moisture to maximum possible at that temperature; expressed as percentage; warm air can hold more moisture than cold air. At 50% RH: air is half saturated; if cooled, RH increases (same moisture, less capacity); at 100% RH, condensation begins. Comfort range typically 30-60% RH. Low RH: dry skin, static; High RH: sticky, mold risk.

questions.question: What is the dew point temperature?

choices.b: Temperature at which air becomes saturated and condensation begins

explanation.short: Dew point is the temperature at which air becomes saturated (100% RH) and water vapor begins condensing.
explanation.detailed: Dew point: temperature where relative humidity reaches 100%; further cooling causes condensation; determined by moisture content of air (not temperature alone); same moisture = same dew point regardless of air temperature. HVAC applications: coil must be below dew point to dehumidify; duct surfaces below dew point will sweat; higher dew point = more humid air. Dew point is better indicator of comfort than RH alone.

questions.question: What does a psychrometric chart show?

choices.b: Relationships between air temperature, humidity, and energy content

explanation.short: A psychrometric chart graphically shows the relationships between dry-bulb, wet-bulb, dew point, humidity, and enthalpy of air.
explanation.detailed: Psychrometric chart shows: dry-bulb temperature (horizontal axis); humidity ratio (vertical axis); relative humidity (curved lines); wet-bulb temperature (diagonal lines); dew point (horizontal from saturation curve); enthalpy (diagonal lines). Uses: determine air conditions from two known properties; track air through HVAC processes; calculate heating/cooling loads; design dehumidification. Essential tool for HVAC engineers.

questions.question: What are the three modes of heat transfer?

choices.b: Conduction, convection, and radiation

explanation.short: Heat transfers by conduction (direct contact), convection (fluid movement), and radiation (electromagnetic waves).
explanation.detailed: Heat transfer modes: Conduction - through solid materials, molecule to molecule contact; Convection - through fluid (air/water) movement, natural or forced; Radiation - electromagnetic waves, no medium required. HVAC examples: conduction through walls, convection in ducts and coils, radiation from sun or warm surfaces. Heat exchangers use all three. Understanding helps troubleshoot and design systems.

questions.question: What does R-value measure?

choices.b: Thermal resistance - ability to resist heat flow

explanation.short: R-value measures thermal resistance - how well a material resists heat flow. Higher R = better insulation.
explanation.detailed: R-value: thermal resistance in hr·ft²·°F/BTU; higher R-value = better insulation = less heat transfer; additive - R-13 wall + R-5 sheathing = R-18 total. U-value is the inverse (1/R) - rate of heat transfer. Required R-values depend on climate zone and building element. Understanding R-values essential for: load calculations, energy codes, insulation selection.

questions.question: What does AFUE measure for furnaces?

choices.b: Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency - percentage of fuel converted to heat

explanation.short: AFUE (Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency) shows what percentage of fuel energy becomes usable heat over a heating season.
explanation.detailed: AFUE: standardized efficiency rating for furnaces/boilers; 80% AFUE = 80% of fuel energy becomes heat, 20% lost up flue; minimum efficiency: 80% AFUE for non-weatherized furnaces; 90%+ AFUE = high-efficiency (condensing). Higher AFUE = lower fuel bills. Doesn't account for: distribution losses, cycling losses, electricity use. Used for comparing equipment and energy code compliance.

questions.question: What does SEER measure for air conditioners?

choices.b: Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio - cooling output per energy input over a season

explanation.short: SEER (Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio) is cooling BTU output divided by electrical watt-hours input over a cooling season.
explanation.detailed: SEER: total cooling BTU ÷ total electrical Wh over typical season; higher SEER = more efficient = lower electricity bills; minimum varies by region (currently 14-15 SEER for split systems in most areas); SEER2 is newer test method reflecting real-world conditions. SEER 16 uses about 20% less energy than SEER 13. Compare SEER when selecting equipment, but also consider initial cost payback.

questions.question: What does HSPF measure for heat pumps?

choices.b: Heating Seasonal Performance Factor - heating efficiency over a season

explanation.short: HSPF (Heating Seasonal Performance Factor) measures heat pump heating efficiency - BTU output per watt-hour input over a heating season.
explanation.detailed: HSPF: total heating BTU ÷ total electrical Wh over heating season; higher HSPF = more efficient heating; includes: defrost cycles, supplemental heat effect, varying outdoor conditions. Minimum HSPF varies (currently 8.2-8.8 depending on region); HSPF2 is newer test standard. Higher HSPF especially valuable in moderate climates where heat pump runs more hours.

questions.question: What is COP (Coefficient of Performance)?

choices.b: Ratio of useful heating/cooling output to energy input

explanation.short: COP is the ratio of useful thermal energy output to electrical energy input - how many units of heat per unit of electricity.
explanation.detailed: COP = useful output ÷ energy input (same units); COP of 3.0 means 3 units of heat per 1 unit of electricity; higher COP = more efficient; varies with conditions (higher at moderate temps). EER ÷ 3.412 = COP (converting BTU to watts). Heat pumps: COP 2-4 typical; Resistance heat: COP = 1.0 (all electricity becomes heat). COP is instantaneous; SEER/HSPF are seasonal averages.

questions.question: What is static pressure in a duct system?

choices.b: Pressure exerted equally in all directions, measured in inches water column

explanation.short: Static pressure is the outward pressure air exerts in all directions within a duct, measured in inches of water column (in. w.c.).
explanation.detailed: Static pressure: pressure exerted perpendicular to airflow; measured with manometer in inches water column (in. w.c.); typical residential: 0.5 in. w.c. external static; high static = restricted airflow (dirty filter, undersized duct); low static = possible duct leak. Total pressure = static + velocity pressure. Static pressure measurement critical for system commissioning and troubleshooting.

questions.question: What does CFM stand for in HVAC?

choices.b: Cubic Feet per Minute - airflow rate

explanation.short: CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute) is the standard unit for measuring airflow rate in HVAC systems.
explanation.detailed: CFM: volume of air moving past a point per minute; typical residential: 400 CFM per ton of cooling; measured with: anemometer, flow hood, duct traverse. Proper CFM critical for: comfort, humidity control, equipment performance. Too little CFM: poor cooling, frozen coil; Too much CFM: poor dehumidification, noise. Balance CFM to match equipment requirements.

questions.question: What is the typical airflow requirement per ton of cooling?

choices.b: 400 CFM per ton

explanation.short: Standard airflow is approximately 400 CFM per ton of cooling capacity.
explanation.detailed: 400 CFM per ton rule: provides proper heat transfer at evaporator; maintains coil above freezing; allows adequate dehumidification. Ranges: 350-450 CFM/ton typical; lower CFM (350) = better dehumidification, colder coil; higher CFM (450) = more sensible cooling, warmer coil. 3-ton system needs approximately 1200 CFM. Manufacturer specifications may vary - always check installation manual.

questions.question: What does the MERV rating indicate for air filters?

choices.b: Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value - particle capture efficiency

explanation.short: MERV (Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value) rates how effectively a filter captures particles of different sizes.
explanation.detailed: MERV scale: 1-20, higher = better filtration; MERV 1-4: basic fiberglass; MERV 8: good residential; MERV 11-13: better allergen capture; MERV 14+: hospital/cleanroom. Trade-off: higher MERV = higher pressure drop = needs larger filter area or more fan power. Don't exceed system's filter rating without verifying airflow. Change filters regularly - dirty filters restrict airflow significantly.

questions.question: What problems can a dirty air filter cause?

choices.b: Reduced airflow, frozen coil, equipment damage, poor comfort

explanation.short: Dirty filters restrict airflow causing frozen coils, reduced efficiency, equipment damage, and poor comfort.
explanation.detailed: Dirty filter consequences: reduced airflow across evaporator; coil temperature drops below freezing; ice forms on coil (frozen evaporator); compressor can slug liquid; blower motor overheats from restricted flow; higher energy bills; poor heating/cooling. Prevention: regular filter changes (monthly during heavy use); proper filter size; customer education. First troubleshooting step: check filter.

questions.question: What is the purpose of mechanical ventilation?

choices.b: Provide fresh outdoor air and remove indoor pollutants

explanation.short: Mechanical ventilation brings in fresh outdoor air and removes stale indoor air to maintain air quality.
explanation.detailed: Ventilation purposes: dilute indoor pollutants (CO2, VOCs, odors); provide oxygen for occupants; remove moisture; meet code requirements. Sources of pollutants: occupants (CO2, bioeffluents); building materials (VOCs); activities (cooking, cleaning). ASHRAE 62.1/62.2 specifies ventilation rates. Tight buildings need mechanical ventilation - can't rely on infiltration. Balance: enough ventilation for air quality, not so much it wastes energy.

questions.question: What rooms typically require mechanical exhaust per code?

choices.b: Bathrooms, kitchens, and utility rooms

explanation.short: Bathrooms, kitchens, laundry rooms, and similar spaces require mechanical exhaust to remove moisture and pollutants.
explanation.detailed: Exhaust requirements: Bathrooms - minimum 50 CFM intermittent or 20 CFM continuous; Kitchens - range hood minimum 100 CFM; Laundry - may require exhaust. Purpose: remove moisture (prevents mold); remove odors; remove combustion products (if applicable). Exhaust must terminate outdoors - not into attic or wall cavity. Makeup air needed for tight homes with large exhaust.

questions.question: When is makeup air required for exhaust systems?

choices.b: When exhaust rate exceeds natural infiltration, creating negative pressure issues

explanation.short: Makeup air is required when exhaust fans create enough negative pressure to cause backdrafting or operational problems.
explanation.detailed: Makeup air needs: tight buildings with large exhaust; prevents negative pressure problems: backdrafting combustion appliances (dangerous); doors hard to open; fan inefficiency. Kitchen exhaust over 400 CFM often requires makeup air per code. Options: passive air inlets, powered makeup air units, interlocked with exhaust. Calculate: total exhaust - infiltration = makeup air needed.

questions.question: Why is an adequate return air path important?

choices.b: Allows air to circulate back to equipment without pressure imbalances

explanation.short: Return air paths allow conditioned air to flow back to the air handler without creating pressure imbalances between rooms.
explanation.detailed: Return air path importance: supply air needs path back to return; closed doors without path create pressure imbalance; room pressurizes positive, reducing supply airflow; hallway depressurizes, drawing unconditioned air. Solutions: door undercuts, transfer grilles, jump ducts, return in each room. ACCA Manual D addresses return path sizing. Common complaint: rooms with closed doors don't condition well.

questions.question: Why must return air not be taken from a garage?

choices.b: Prevents drawing car exhaust and contaminants into living space

explanation.short: Return air from garages is prohibited because it could draw carbon monoxide and other contaminants into occupied spaces.
explanation.detailed: Garage air prohibition: vehicles produce CO during starting/running; gasoline vapors present; other stored chemicals. Duct system could distribute contaminants throughout home. Requirements: no return air from garage; supply ducts through garage must be sealed/insulated; HVAC equipment in garage requires separation from living space. Fire separation also required between garage and living space.

questions.question: When is duct insulation required?

choices.b: When ducts pass through unconditioned spaces

explanation.short: Ducts passing through unconditioned spaces (attics, crawlspaces, garages) require insulation to prevent energy loss.
explanation.detailed: Duct insulation requirements: supply ducts in unconditioned spaces: R-6 to R-8 typical (varies by climate); return ducts in unconditioned spaces: similar requirements; ducts in conditioned space: may not require insulation. Also prevents: condensation on cold supply ducts; heat gain/loss affecting delivery temperature. Seal duct joints before insulating. Insulation also provides vapor barrier for cold ducts.

questions.question: Why is duct sealing important?

choices.b: Prevents conditioned air loss and prevents drawing in unconditioned/contaminated air

explanation.short: Duct sealing prevents energy waste from conditioned air leaking out and unconditioned air being drawn in.
explanation.detailed: Duct sealing importance: supply leaks lose conditioned air to unconditioned space (energy waste); return leaks draw unconditioned air (efficiency loss, potential contaminants); leaks can be 20-30% of airflow in older systems. Sealing methods: mastic (best), foil tape (UL 181), mechanical fasteners. Focus on: connections, joints, boots, plenums. Modern codes require testing: duct blaster test or total leakage limits.

questions.question: Where should a thermostat be located for best performance?

choices.b: Interior wall, away from heat sources, at breathing height, central location

explanation.short: Thermostats should be on interior walls, away from heat sources, at 5 feet height, in a central location for accurate sensing.
explanation.detailed: Thermostat placement: interior wall (stable temperature); approximately 5 feet height (breathing zone); away from: direct sunlight, supply registers, heat sources (lamps, TV, appliances), exterior walls, drafts. Central location senses average home temperature. Poor placement causes: short cycling, temperature swings, comfort complaints. Wireless sensors can compensate for suboptimal thermostat location.

questions.question: What is HVAC commissioning?

choices.b: Systematic process of verifying system performs per design intent

explanation.short: Commissioning verifies that HVAC systems are installed correctly and perform according to design specifications.
explanation.detailed: Commissioning includes: verify airflow (CFM per room and total); verify refrigerant charge (superheat/subcooling); check static pressures; verify temperatures (supply, return, delta-T); test controls sequence; verify safety devices operate; document all measurements. ACCA Standard 5 covers commissioning. Benefits: optimal performance, energy efficiency, fewer callbacks, customer satisfaction. Should be done on every installation.

questions.question: When do manufacturer's installation instructions take precedence?

choices.b: When they are more restrictive than code requirements

explanation.short: Manufacturer's instructions take precedence when more restrictive than code because equipment is listed based on those instructions.
explanation.detailed: Manufacturer instruction hierarchy: equipment is tested and listed under specific conditions; listing requires installation per manufacturer; code is minimum requirement; if manufacturer requires MORE than code (greater clearance, specific venting, etc.), manufacturer wins. Violating manufacturer instructions: may void listing; can void warranty; is code violation. Always read and follow installation manual.

questions.question: Why is proper HVAC equipment sizing important?

choices.b: Ensures comfort, efficiency, humidity control, and equipment longevity

explanation.short: Proper sizing ensures comfort, efficiency, humidity control, and prevents equipment damage from short-cycling.
explanation.detailed: Sizing importance: Oversized equipment: short cycles, poor humidity control, temperature swings, increased wear, higher cost; Undersized equipment: can't meet load on design days, runs continuously, comfort complaints. Proper sizing: uses load calculation (Manual J); matches equipment to calculated load; considers local climate design conditions. Industry standard is ACCA Manual J residential, Manual N commercial.

questions.question: What documentation should be left with the customer after HVAC installation?

choices.b: Equipment manuals, warranty info, filter size, maintenance instructions

explanation.short: Customers should receive equipment manuals, warranty registration, filter size/type, and maintenance instructions.
explanation.detailed: Installation documentation: equipment manuals (installation and operation); warranty registration information; filter size and replacement schedule; thermostat programming instructions; emergency contact information; maintenance recommendations; commissioning data (optional but professional). Some jurisdictions require leaving manuals. Good documentation: reduces callbacks, ensures warranty compliance, demonstrates professionalism.

questions.question: What is the purpose of lockout/tagout procedures?

choices.b: To prevent unexpected equipment startup during service

explanation.short: Lockout/tagout prevents unexpected energization of equipment during service, protecting workers from injury.
explanation.detailed: Lockout/tagout (LOTO): de-energize equipment; apply lock to disconnect preventing re-energization; apply tag identifying who locked it out; verify energy is isolated (try to start). Applies to: electrical, mechanical, pneumatic, hydraulic energy. OSHA 29 CFR 1910.147 requires LOTO program. Each worker applies their own lock. Never remove another person's lock.

questions.question: What PPE is typically required for HVAC service work?

choices.b: Safety glasses, gloves, appropriate footwear at minimum

explanation.short: Basic PPE includes safety glasses, work gloves, and appropriate footwear; additional PPE based on specific hazards.
explanation.detailed: Minimum PPE: safety glasses (flying debris, refrigerant); work gloves (sharp edges, chemicals, temperature); closed-toe shoes/boots. Additional based on task: hearing protection (loud equipment); respirator (insulation, chemicals); hard hat (overhead hazards); electrical gloves (live work). Employer must provide PPE and train on use. PPE is last line of defense - eliminate hazards first.

questions.question: What is the proper angle for setting up an extension ladder?

choices.b: 4:1 ratio - base 1 foot out for every 4 feet of height

explanation.short: Extension ladders should be set at a 4:1 ratio - the base positioned 1 foot out for every 4 feet of working height.
explanation.detailed: Ladder safety 4:1 rule: prevents tipping backward (too steep) or sliding out (too shallow). Additional rules: extend 3 feet above landing; secure top and/or bottom; face ladder when climbing; maintain 3-point contact; don't overreach; inspect before use. Weight rating must exceed user plus tools/materials. Many HVAC injuries involve ladder falls.

questions.question: What are signs of heat exhaustion?

choices.b: Heavy sweating, weakness, cool/pale/clammy skin, nausea

explanation.short: Heat exhaustion symptoms include heavy sweating, weakness, cool and clammy skin, nausea, and possible fainting.
explanation.detailed: Heat exhaustion: body overheating but still sweating; symptoms: heavy sweating, weakness, cold/pale/clammy skin, fast/weak pulse, nausea/vomiting, fainting. Treatment: move to cool place, loosen clothing, cool wet cloths, sip water. If untreated, can progress to heat stroke (medical emergency - hot/dry skin, confusion, loss of consciousness). Prevention: hydrate, take breaks, acclimatize, recognize early signs.

questions.question: What should be assumed about electrical circuits until verified?

choices.b: They are energized and dangerous

explanation.short: Always assume electrical circuits are energized until verified de-energized with a properly working meter.
explanation.detailed: Electrical safety principle: assume energized until proven otherwise; verify with tested meter (test meter on known live source first); lock out before working; even 'low voltage' can be dangerous. Common HVAC voltages: 24V control, 120V, 240V, 208V, 480V. Arc flash hazard at higher voltages. NFPA 70E covers electrical safety. More electricians die from 120V than higher voltages (complacency).

questions.question: What defines a permit-required confined space?

choices.b: Space with limited entry/exit and potential for hazardous atmosphere or engulfment

explanation.short: Permit-required confined spaces have limited entry/exit and contain or potentially contain hazardous atmospheres, engulfment hazards, or other serious dangers.
explanation.detailed: Confined space criteria: large enough to enter and work; limited means of entry/exit; not designed for continuous occupancy. Permit-required if: hazardous atmosphere (toxic, oxygen-deficient, flammable); engulfment hazard; converging walls; other serious hazard. Examples: tanks, vessels, some crawlspaces, manholes. Requires: entry permit, attendant, rescue plan, atmospheric testing, ventilation.

questions.question: What class of fire extinguisher is appropriate for electrical fires?

choices.b: Class B only

explanation.short: Class C fire extinguishers are rated for electrical fires; ABC extinguishers cover ordinary, flammable liquid, and electrical fires.
explanation.detailed: Fire extinguisher classes: A = ordinary combustibles (wood, paper); B = flammable liquids; C = electrical; D = combustible metals; K = cooking oils. For HVAC work: ABC extinguisher is versatile; Class C important for electrical fires. NEVER use water on electrical fire. PASS technique: Pull pin, Aim low, Squeeze handle, Sweep side to side. Know extinguisher locations on job sites.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of mechanical codes?

choices.b: To establish minimum standards for public health and safety

explanation.short: Mechanical codes establish minimum standards to protect public health, safety, and welfare.
explanation.detailed: Code purpose: protect occupants from hazards; ensure minimum acceptable performance; provide consistent standards across jurisdictions; codes are MINIMUM requirements - can exceed but not reduce. Hazards addressed: fire, explosion, toxic gases, structural failure, electrical shock. Code compliance is legal requirement. Codes are updated on 3-year cycle to incorporate new technology and lessons learned.

questions.question: When should mechanical work be inspected?

choices.b: At required stages before concealment and upon completion

explanation.short: Inspections are required at specified stages before work is concealed and upon final completion.
explanation.detailed: Inspection requirements: rough-in inspection before concealment (ductwork, piping, venting); final inspection after completion; additional inspections as required by permit. Purpose: verify code compliance; catch problems before they're hidden; ensure safety. Never conceal work before required inspection. Inspector has authority to require corrections. Good relationship with inspectors benefits everyone.

questions.question: What factors determine gas pipe sizing?

choices.b: BTU load, pipe length, allowable pressure drop, specific gravity

explanation.short: Gas pipe sizing depends on total BTU demand, developed length, allowable pressure drop, and gas specific gravity.
explanation.detailed: Gas pipe sizing factors: total connected load (BTU/hr); developed length (longest run to farthest appliance); allowable pressure drop (typically 0.5 in. w.c.); gas specific gravity (natural gas = 0.60, propane = 1.50). Use sizing tables in IFGC or NFPA 54. Undersized pipe: appliances starved for gas, poor combustion, CO production. Always size for total possible load, not just current equipment.

questions.question: What is the typical delivery pressure for natural gas at residential appliances?

choices.b: 7 inches water column (about 0.25 psi)

explanation.short: Natural gas is typically delivered at 7 inches water column (in. w.c.) pressure at residential appliances.
explanation.detailed: Natural gas pressures: utility delivers at higher pressure; regulator at meter reduces to 7 in. w.c. typical; some appliances have additional regulator for specific pressure. LP gas: typically 11 in. w.c. at appliance. Measure with manometer at appliance while operating. Low pressure: incomplete combustion, insufficient heat. High pressure: overfiring, damage, safety hazard. Always verify correct pressure.

questions.question: What is manifold pressure on a gas furnace?

choices.b: Pressure at the burner orifices, after the gas valve

explanation.short: Manifold pressure is the gas pressure at the burner manifold/orifices, measured at the pressure tap after the gas valve.
explanation.detailed: Manifold pressure: measured at test port on gas valve outlet; determines gas flow rate through orifices; typical natural gas: 3.5 in. w.c.; LP gas: 10-11 in. w.c. Adjustment: high manifold = overfiring, flame lifting; low manifold = underfiring, CO. Verify against manufacturer specifications for specific equipment. Always measure and adjust at commissioning.

questions.question: What color should a properly adjusted natural gas flame be?

choices.b: Blue with possible small yellow tips

explanation.short: A properly adjusted natural gas flame is mostly blue with possible small yellow tips; solid yellow indicates incomplete combustion.
explanation.detailed: Flame color indicates combustion quality: Blue flame = complete combustion, good air/fuel mix; Yellow/orange = incomplete combustion, insufficient air, produces CO; Lifting flame = too much primary air; Floating/lazy flame = draft problem. Check flame through sight glass while operating. Dirty burners, blocked air openings, or improper gas pressure affect flame quality.

questions.question: What causes natural draft in a flue or chimney?

choices.b: Hot gases rising due to density difference from surrounding air

explanation.short: Natural draft occurs because hot flue gases are less dense than surrounding air and rise, creating negative pressure that draws combustion products up.
explanation.detailed: Natural draft principles: hot gas is less dense than cold; lighter gas rises (buoyancy); creates negative pressure in appliance; draws combustion air in and products up. Factors affecting draft: flue gas temperature, flue height, outdoor temperature, wind, obstructions. Draft problems: spillage, CO in building, poor combustion. Test with smoke pencil at draft hood. Category I appliances rely on natural draft.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a draft hood (diverter) on a Category I appliance?

choices.b: Prevent downdrafts from affecting burner and allow dilution air

explanation.short: Draft hoods prevent downdrafts from extinguishing the burner and allow dilution air to mix with flue gases.
explanation.detailed: Draft hood functions: isolates burner from chimney draft fluctuations; allows dilution air to enter, reducing flue gas dew point; provides relief path if chimney is blocked; allows spillage inspection point. Located between appliance and vent connector. If spillage occurs (smoke/CO at draft hood), indicates draft problem. Only on Category I (natural draft) appliances.

questions.question: How does an induced draft furnace differ from natural draft?

choices.b: Uses a fan to pull combustion products through heat exchanger

explanation.short: Induced draft furnaces use a fan (inducer motor) to pull combustion gases through the heat exchanger and up the flue.
explanation.detailed: Induced draft: fan located at outlet of heat exchanger; creates negative pressure through heat exchanger; doesn't rely solely on buoyancy; more consistent draft regardless of conditions; allows smaller vent sizes; proves venting before gas valve opens. Sequence: inducer starts, pressure switch proves draft, ignition sequence begins. Most 80% AFUE furnaces are induced draft.

questions.question: What does the pressure switch prove in an induced draft furnace?

choices.b: That the inducer is running and vent path is clear

explanation.short: The pressure switch verifies the inducer motor is creating proper draft and the vent path is not blocked.
explanation.detailed: Pressure switch function: senses negative pressure created by inducer; closes when adequate draft is achieved; control board won't proceed to ignition until switch closes. If switch doesn't close: inducer problem, blocked vent, switch failure, tubing issue. Diagnostic: measure pressure at switch; compare to switch rating; check tubing for blockage/moisture. Critical safety device - never bypass.

questions.question: What causes a furnace high limit switch to open?

choices.b: Excessive heat exchanger temperature, typically from restricted airflow

explanation.short: The high limit opens when heat exchanger temperature exceeds safe limits, usually due to restricted airflow from dirty filters or blocked ducts.
explanation.detailed: High limit function: monitors heat exchanger temperature; opens to stop gas flow if overheating; protects heat exchanger from damage; resets when temperature drops. Common causes: dirty filter (most common); blocked return; closed registers; failed blower motor; wrong blower speed. Limit cycling indicates problem - don't just reset. Fix root cause to prevent heat exchanger damage.

questions.question: How does a flame rectification sensor work?

choices.b: Detects electrical current flow through flame (flame conducts DC)

explanation.short: Flame rectification sensors detect the small DC current that flows when flame is present between sensor rod and ground.
explanation.detailed: Flame rectification: flame conducts electricity; AC applied to sensor; flame allows current in one direction (rectifies to DC); control board detects microamp current (1-6 µA typical). No flame = no current = gas valve closes. Common problem: dirty sensor (carbon buildup insulates). Cleaning: fine abrasive pad, not sandpaper. If current is low, furnace may light then lockout.

questions.question: What are common ignition methods in modern gas furnaces?

choices.b: Hot surface ignition (HSI) and direct spark ignition (DSI)

explanation.short: Modern furnaces use hot surface ignition (HSI) with silicon carbide or nitride igniters, or direct spark ignition (DSI).
explanation.detailed: Modern ignition systems: HSI (hot surface ignition) - silicon carbide or silicon nitride element glows hot (1800°F+); DSI (direct spark) - spark electrode ignites gas directly. Both eliminate standing pilot waste. HSI more common in residential; igniters are fragile, handle carefully. Sequence: inducer starts, igniter energizes, gas valve opens, flame established, igniter de-energizes. Standing pilots now rare.

questions.question: Why is there a delay before the blower starts in a gas furnace heating cycle?

choices.b: Allow heat exchanger to warm up before circulating air

explanation.short: The blower delay allows the heat exchanger to warm up, preventing cold air from being blown initially.
explanation.detailed: Blower on-delay: typically 30-90 seconds after burner lights; allows heat exchanger to reach operating temperature; prevents cold air blast at cycle start; improves comfort. Blower off-delay: blower continues 90-180 seconds after burner stops; extracts remaining heat from exchanger; improves efficiency. Controlled by fan timer on board or thermostat. Delays are adjustable on many systems.

questions.question: What does a flame rollout switch protect against?

choices.b: Flames burning outside the combustion chamber due to blocked heat exchanger

explanation.short: Flame rollout switches detect flames escaping the combustion chamber, indicating a blocked heat exchanger or cracked heat exchanger.
explanation.detailed: Rollout switch function: located near burner opening; opens if flame extends beyond normal area; indicates serious problem: blocked flue, cracked heat exchanger, excessive gas pressure. Usually manual reset - requires service. Don't simply reset without finding cause. Rolled-out flames can ignite wiring, damage components, cause fire. Critical safety device protecting against fire and CO.

questions.question: Why do high-efficiency furnaces require condensate traps?

choices.b: To maintain pressure differential and prevent flue gases from escaping through drain

explanation.short: Condensate traps maintain the pressure seal, preventing positive flue gas pressure from pushing CO out through the drain line.
explanation.detailed: High-efficiency trap requirements: 90%+ furnaces operate under positive pressure; without trap, flue gases would exit through condensate drain; trap water column seals against pressure. Trap depth must exceed operating pressure. Common issues: dry trap (seal lost), blocked trap, improper trap installation. Trap must remain filled with water during operation. Some furnaces have integral traps.

questions.question: What is the benefit of a two-stage furnace?

choices.b: Runs at lower output most of the time for improved comfort and efficiency

explanation.short: Two-stage furnaces run at lower output (60-70%) most of the time, providing longer run cycles, better comfort, and improved efficiency.
explanation.detailed: Two-stage operation: low fire (60-70% capacity) handles most heating needs; high fire for coldest conditions or recovery; longer run times = more even temperature; better air mixing; improved filtration time; quieter at low stage. Controlled by: thermostat demand, outdoor temperature, or timed staging. Higher efficiency at low fire due to better heat transfer. More comfortable than single-stage.

questions.question: What technology do variable-speed blower motors use?

choices.b: ECM (Electronically Commutated Motor) or brushless DC

explanation.short: Variable-speed blowers use ECM (Electronically Commutated Motors), which are brushless DC motors with electronic controls.
explanation.detailed: ECM technology: converts AC to DC internally; electronic commutation (no brushes); can vary speed infinitely; maintains CFM despite static pressure changes; very efficient (70%+ vs 60% for PSC). Benefits: constant airflow, quiet operation, lower electric bills, better dehumidification. Can be programmed for specific CFM or torque. Standard in high-efficiency systems, increasingly common overall.

questions.question: How does a heat pump differ from a standard air conditioner?

choices.b: Heat pump can reverse refrigerant flow to provide both heating and cooling

explanation.short: Heat pumps include a reversing valve that allows the refrigerant flow to reverse, enabling both heating and cooling from one system.
explanation.detailed: Heat pump operation: contains reversing valve (4-way valve); cooling mode: indoor coil is evaporator (absorbs heat); heating mode: indoor coil is condenser (releases heat). Same refrigeration cycle, reversed direction. Advantages: efficient heating (COP 2-4), single system for both modes. Limitations: capacity and efficiency decrease in very cold weather; may need supplemental heat.

questions.question: Why do heat pumps need a defrost cycle?

choices.b: To melt ice that forms on outdoor coil during heating mode

explanation.short: In heating mode, the outdoor coil operates below freezing and can accumulate ice; defrost cycle reverses to melt it.
explanation.detailed: Defrost necessity: outdoor coil absorbs heat from cold air; coil temperature below 32°F; moisture in air frosts on coil; ice buildup blocks airflow, reduces efficiency. Defrost cycle: reverses to cooling mode temporarily; hot refrigerant melts ice; takes 1-10 minutes; backup heat may run to temper supply air. Initiated by: time/temperature, demand (pressure or temperature differential).

questions.question: What is auxiliary/emergency heat in a heat pump system?

choices.b: Supplemental electric or gas heat for cold weather or backup

explanation.short: Auxiliary heat supplements the heat pump during cold weather or provides emergency backup if the heat pump fails.
explanation.detailed: Auxiliary/emergency heat: supplements heat pump when capacity insufficient; typically electric resistance strips (expensive to run) or gas furnace (dual fuel); auxiliary = supplements compressor; emergency = compressor off, backup only. Control: thermostat activates based on temperature differential or outdoor temperature lockout. Dual fuel systems: heat pump above 35-40°F, gas furnace below. Minimize auxiliary use for efficiency.

questions.question: What is a ductless mini-split system?

choices.b: Split system with wall-mounted indoor unit(s) connected to outdoor unit without ductwork

explanation.short: Ductless mini-splits have indoor wall/ceiling units connected to an outdoor unit by refrigerant lines, without ductwork.
explanation.detailed: Mini-split features: indoor unit(s) mounted on wall or ceiling; outdoor compressor/condenser unit; connected by refrigerant lines, power, and control wiring; no ductwork required. Benefits: zone control, high efficiency (often inverter-driven), easy retrofit, no duct losses. Multi-zone: one outdoor unit serves multiple indoor units. Common for additions, older homes, or room-by-room control.

questions.question: How does an inverter-driven compressor improve efficiency?

choices.b: Varies speed to match load, avoiding on/off cycling losses

explanation.short: Inverter compressors vary speed to match the actual load, running continuously at lower speeds rather than cycling on and off.
explanation.detailed: Inverter technology: variable frequency drive controls compressor speed; matches output to load in real-time; runs continuously at partial load; avoids startup surge (highest energy draw); maintains more consistent temperature. Benefits: 30%+ energy savings, better comfort, quieter operation, longer compressor life. Standard on mini-splits, increasingly common in ducted systems.

questions.question: What is the heat source/sink for a ground-source (geothermal) heat pump?

choices.b: Earth or groundwater at stable temperature

explanation.short: Ground-source heat pumps exchange heat with the earth or groundwater, which maintains a stable temperature year-round.
explanation.detailed: Ground-source heat pumps: ground loop circulates water/antifreeze through buried pipes; earth temperature stable (50-60°F in most US); heating: extracts heat from ground; cooling: rejects heat to ground. Types: horizontal loops, vertical boreholes, open loop (well water). Benefits: highest efficiency (COP 4-5), no outdoor unit, quiet. Higher installation cost but lower operating cost than air-source.

questions.question: What is HVAC zoning?

choices.b: Dividing a building into separately controlled temperature areas

explanation.short: Zoning divides a building into separate areas with independent temperature control using dampers or multiple systems.
explanation.detailed: Zoning methods: motorized dampers in ductwork with zone thermostats; bypass damper for pressure relief; zone control panel coordinates operation. Benefits: different temperatures in different areas; compensates for varying loads (sun exposure, occupancy); improved comfort. Challenges: proper damper sizing, equipment compatibility, bypass or dump zone needs. ACCA Manual Zr covers residential zoning design.

questions.question: What does IAQ stand for in HVAC?

choices.b: Indoor Air Quality

explanation.short: IAQ (Indoor Air Quality) refers to the quality of air inside buildings as it relates to health and comfort.
explanation.detailed: IAQ factors: pollutant concentrations (CO2, VOCs, particulates, CO, mold); temperature and humidity; ventilation adequacy; odors. Sources of poor IAQ: inadequate ventilation, combustion products, building materials off-gassing, occupant activities, outdoor air pollution. HVAC role: provide ventilation, filter particles, control humidity. Growing importance with tighter buildings. ASHRAE 62 sets ventilation standards for acceptable IAQ.

questions.question: What indoor CO2 level indicates inadequate ventilation?

choices.b: Above 1000 ppm

explanation.short: Indoor CO2 above 1000 ppm typically indicates inadequate ventilation; outdoor air is about 400 ppm.
explanation.detailed: CO2 as ventilation indicator: outdoor air ~400 ppm; occupants exhale CO2; level rises without adequate ventilation; ASHRAE 62 uses 700 ppm above outdoor (1100 ppm total) as ventilation adequacy benchmark; above 1000 ppm suggests stuffiness; 2000+ ppm indicates serious ventilation problem. CO2 sensors used for demand-controlled ventilation. Note: CO2 not toxic at these levels but indicates other pollutant buildup.

questions.question: Why might humidification be needed in heating climates?

choices.b: Cold air holds less moisture; heating it drops relative humidity uncomfortably low

explanation.short: Cold outdoor air has low moisture content; heating it without adding moisture results in very low relative humidity indoors.
explanation.detailed: Winter humidity problem: cold air holds little moisture (low absolute humidity); heated to 70°F, relative humidity drops to 10-20%; causes: dry skin, static, respiratory irritation, wood damage. Solution: humidifiers add moisture - types include bypass, fan-powered, steam. Target 30-50% RH. IMC requires backflow prevention on water supply. Over-humidification causes condensation on windows, mold risk.

questions.question: How do air conditioning systems dehumidify?

choices.b: By cooling air below dew point, condensing moisture on evaporator coil

explanation.short: AC systems cool air below its dew point, causing water vapor to condense on the evaporator coil and drain away.
explanation.detailed: Dehumidification process: air passes over cold evaporator coil; coil temperature below dew point; moisture condenses on coil fins; water drains to condensate pan and out. Factors affecting dehumidification: coil temperature (colder = more moisture removed); airflow (slower = more contact time = more moisture removed); entering air conditions. Oversized equipment short-cycles, reducing dehumidification effectiveness.

questions.question: What does an ERV (Energy Recovery Ventilator) do?

choices.b: Transfer heat AND moisture between exhaust and supply air streams

explanation.short: ERVs transfer both heat and moisture (enthalpy) between outgoing exhaust air and incoming fresh air, reducing ventilation energy costs.
explanation.detailed: ERV operation: two separate air streams (exhaust and supply) pass through heat exchanger; heat and moisture transfer through membrane or wheel; winter: warms and humidifies incoming cold dry air; summer: pre-cools and dehumidifies incoming hot humid air. Differs from HRV (Heat Recovery Ventilator) which transfers only heat, not moisture. Best for climates with humidity extremes. Required by some energy codes.

questions.question: How do UV lights improve indoor air quality in HVAC systems?

choices.b: UV-C light kills/inactivates mold, bacteria, and some viruses on surfaces and in air

explanation.short: UV-C germicidal lights kill or inactivate microorganisms including mold on coils and bacteria/viruses in the air stream.
explanation.detailed: UV germicidal irradiation (UVGI): UV-C wavelength (254nm) damages DNA/RNA of microorganisms; coil irradiation: continuous exposure keeps coil free of biofilm; air disinfection: UV in air stream, requires adequate exposure time. Benefits: cleaner coil, reduced mold/odors, potential pathogen reduction. Limitations: doesn't filter particles, bulb replacement needed annually, safety precautions required (don't look at UV).

questions.question: Why is proper refrigerant line sizing critical?

choices.b: Ensures proper oil return, capacity, and prevents excessive pressure drop

explanation.short: Proper line sizing ensures adequate refrigerant velocity for oil return, maintains capacity, and prevents excessive pressure drop.
explanation.detailed: Line sizing considerations: suction line - large enough for low pressure drop, small enough for oil return velocity; liquid line - sized for pressure drop; vertical lift affects sizing (oil must return uphill). Undersized: excessive pressure drop, capacity loss, noise. Oversized suction: oil logging (especially at part load). Manufacturer line sizing charts consider: capacity, refrigerant, line length, lift. Critical for long line sets.

questions.question: When are suction line traps required?

choices.b: When suction line rises vertically, to assist oil return at low loads

explanation.short: Suction line traps are installed at the base of vertical risers to collect oil and ensure it returns to the compressor.
explanation.detailed: Suction line trap purpose: oil travels with refrigerant; at low velocities, oil may not climb vertical sections; trap at bottom of riser collects oil; slug of refrigerant/oil periodically pushed up when trap fills. Installation: trap at bottom of each riser; trap every 20-25 feet of rise. Not always required with variable-speed systems (velocity maintained). Check manufacturer recommendations for specific equipment.

questions.question: What safety precaution is essential when brazing refrigerant lines?

choices.b: Flow nitrogen through the line to prevent oxidation and never braze with refrigerant present

explanation.short: Always flow nitrogen through lines when brazing to prevent internal oxidation, and NEVER braze with refrigerant in the system.
explanation.detailed: Brazing safety and quality: nitrogen purge prevents internal oxide formation (scale blocks TXV, damages compressor); flow nitrogen before, during, and after brazing. NEVER braze with refrigerant present - creates toxic phosgene gas. Have fire extinguisher ready; protect combustibles; use heat shield. Proper technique: heat tube not fitting, capillary action draws alloy. Good joint requires proper cleaning, flux (on copper-brass), correct alloy.

questions.question: What is the first step in HVAC troubleshooting?

choices.b: Gather information - customer complaint, history, observation

explanation.short: Effective troubleshooting starts with gathering information: understand the complaint, history, and make observations.
explanation.detailed: Troubleshooting process: (1) Gather info - what's the complaint, when did it start, what changed, system history; (2) Verify - confirm the problem exists; (3) Analyze - use logical approach based on symptoms; (4) Test - measure relevant parameters; (5) Diagnose - identify root cause; (6) Repair - fix the actual problem; (7) Verify - confirm repair resolved issue. Avoid parts-changing approach - expensive and often ineffective.

questions.question: What is a normal temperature difference (Delta-T) across an air conditioning evaporator?

explanation.short: Normal Delta-T across the evaporator is 15-22°F (supply air 15-22°F cooler than return air).
explanation.detailed: Delta-T diagnosis: measure return air and supply air temperatures; difference should be 15-22°F (varies with humidity). Low Delta-T (<15°F): low refrigerant, restricted airflow, dirty coil, low load. High Delta-T (>22°F): low airflow (dirty filter, closed registers), oversized equipment. Quick check for proper operation. Must consider actual conditions - high humidity can increase Delta-T.

questions.question: What does high compressor amp draw typically indicate?

choices.b: Possible mechanical problems, high head pressure, or electrical issues

explanation.short: High amp draw can indicate mechanical problems, high head pressure (dirty condenser, overcharge), or electrical issues.
explanation.detailed: High amp diagnosis: compare to RLA (Rated Load Amps) on nameplate; causes: high head pressure (dirty condenser, airflow restriction, overcharge, non-condensables); mechanical problem (worn bearings, tight compressor); low voltage (amps rise to compensate); single-phasing (3-phase). Low amps can indicate: low charge, low load, failing compressor (not pumping). Amp reading is quick diagnostic tool.

questions.question: How is a motor run capacitor tested?

choices.b: Measure capacitance with meter; compare to rated value (within 6%)

explanation.short: Test capacitors with a capacitance meter; the reading should be within ±6% of the rated microfarad value.
explanation.detailed: Capacitor testing: SAFETY - discharge capacitor first (resistor between terminals); measure microfarads with capacitor function on meter; compare to rating on capacitor. Good: within ±6% of rated value; Weak: below range, may work but cause problems; Failed: far out of range or open/shorted. Symptoms of bad capacitor: motor won't start, hums, overheats, runs slow. Common failure in hot equipment compartments.

questions.question: What causes contactor contacts to become pitted or burned?

choices.a: Normal wear from repeated cycling and electrical arcing
choices.b: Low refrigerant

explanation.short: Contactor contacts wear from normal cycling - electrical arcing each time contacts open/close gradually pits and burns the surfaces.
explanation.detailed: Contactor wear: electrical arc occurs when contacts open; arc erodes contact material over time; pitted contacts increase resistance; increased resistance causes heating, voltage drop; eventually contacts weld closed or won't conduct. Inspection: look for pitting, discoloration, carbon buildup; check for chattering (weak coil); measure voltage drop across closed contacts. Replace when worn - cheap part prevents expensive failures.

questions.question: What are signs of a refrigerant leak in a cooling system?

choices.b: Reduced cooling, ice on lines, oil stains, low subcooling/high superheat

explanation.short: Leak signs include reduced cooling capacity, ice on suction line or coil, oil stains at leak points, and abnormal superheat/subcooling.
explanation.detailed: Refrigerant leak indicators: gradual capacity loss; suction pressure drops over time; high superheat (not enough refrigerant); low subcooling; icing on suction line (starving evaporator); oil stains at joints (oil travels with refrigerant); bubbles in sight glass. If low charge suspected: find and fix leak before adding refrigerant. Simply recharging doesn't fix problem - it will leak out again.

questions.question: What documentation is typically required to maintain equipment warranty?

choices.b: Proof of proper installation, registration, and regular maintenance records

explanation.short: Warranties typically require proof of proper installation, timely registration, and evidence of regular maintenance.
explanation.detailed: Warranty requirements vary but commonly include: installation by qualified contractor; permit and inspection (some manufacturers); warranty registration (often within 60-90 days); regular maintenance documentation (filter changes, annual tune-ups). Failure to meet requirements can void warranty. Help customers: register equipment; explain maintenance requirements; provide maintenance records. Document installation thoroughly.

questions.question: Why is regular HVAC maintenance important?

choices.b: Maintains efficiency, prevents breakdowns, extends equipment life, ensures safety

explanation.short: Regular maintenance keeps equipment efficient, prevents costly breakdowns, extends service life, and ensures safe operation.
explanation.detailed: Maintenance benefits: efficiency - dirty equipment works harder, uses more energy; reliability - catch problems before failures; longevity - properly maintained equipment lasts longer; safety - verify combustion, electrical, refrigerant integrity; comfort - consistent performance. Typical maintenance: filter changes, coil cleaning, electrical checks, refrigerant charge verification, safety testing. Pays for itself in efficiency and avoided repairs.

questions.question: What defines a professional HVAC technician?

choices.b: Technical competence, ethical conduct, continuous learning, and customer service

explanation.short: Professional technicians combine technical competence with ethical conduct, ongoing education, and quality customer service.
explanation.detailed: Professionalism includes: technical competence - proper training, certifications, skills; ethical conduct - honest diagnosis, fair pricing, doing the right thing; continuous learning - technology changes, codes update, stay current; customer service - communication, cleanliness, respect for property; safety - protect yourself, coworkers, customers, and property. Reputation and career built on professionalism. Industry needs skilled, ethical professionals.
